description: From French citadelle, from Italian cittadella, diminutive of città (“city”), from Latin cīvitās.

entries.meaning: A strong fortress that sits high above a city.
(sometimes figurative) A stronghold or fortified place.
examples: Intrenched within the citadel of our apartment, and cheered by the comfortings of a coal fire, we passed the day in letter-writing, conversation, or gazing from the sheltered security of our windows upon the agitated sea […]

entries.meaning: An armoured portion of a warship, housing important equipment.
examples: Twenty-two of these — eleven per broadside — were on the main deck within a central citadel, essentially an armor-protected box in the middle of the ship. Also within the citadel were four 110-pdr. breech-loaders.
